questions.question_text: kerning is to letter-spacing as leading is to _______.
questions.explanation: The only valid CSS property is the correct answer, line-height. None of the other properties exist. See page 283 in HTML & CSS for details.

questions.question_text: true or false: :first-line is an example of a pseudo-selector.
questions.explanation: It’s an example of a pseudo-element. A pseudo-element acts like an extra element is in the code. See page 289 in HTML & CSS for details.

questions.question_text: how many link states can be styled?
questions.explanation: :link, :visited, :hover, :active, and :focus. See pages 290–291 in HTML & CSS for details.

questions.question_text: the following css properties can have transitions except...
questions.explanation: Virtually all properties whose values are numeric can be animated (a handy time to remember that colors can be represented numerically). The values for display are not numeric.

questions.question_text: according to dan cederholm, animation on the web should be used...
questions.explanation: “Like all shiny new tools, it’s important to use transitions appropriately. One can easily go overboard adding transitions to everything on the page, resulting in some sort of annoying, pulsating monster. It’s key to decide where transitions rightfully enrich the user experience and when they are just extraneous noise.” –Dan Cederholm, CSS3 for Web Designers, page 26

questions.question_text:
the css snippet below...
p {
color: brown;
transition: color .3s ease ;
}
...will do what when someone hovers over a hypothetical paragraph element?

answers.answer_text: turn the text brown over the course of 3 seconds
turn the text brown over the course of 300 milliseconds
we don’t know what it will do

questions.explanation:
In order for something to happen, we would need to define a second rule for the hover state: p:hover { ... }. We would have to add a declaration with the color property to change the color, which it would do over the course of 300 milliseconds per the first rule.

Note that transitions are assigned to the mouse-off state rule, not the hover state rule.
